Memoirs of a Life

                                                                                        From



                                                                        My note book and journal,

                                                                       with additions and reflections

                                                                                       Volume 1

Many of the sketches of character and incidents
herein transcribed here have been published
in New York weekly papers under the "noms de plume"
of "Timothy Busy" and "Peter Piper."  My note book
and journal was commenced at twelve years of age
and kept as regularly as circumstances could admit
until the end of the year 1844.  From that time until the
present year (1867) I have had to draw upon memory in 
a great measure
H.H Knelling

Memoirs of a Life
Chapter. 1. 
Birth, parentage and childhood. Council Bluffs, St. Peters. Want. A ducking. Fort Smelling etc.
Being persuaded that all things were and are created for the honor and glory of God, and that nothing was ever created in vain; and believing that man is no exception to this truth, but that above all other created things he was made for the same end; and also believing that every human life is a "living epistle to be read of all men"; and that no one is so humble that he cannot testify to the wonderful goodness, mercy, loving kindness and power of Almighty God, I sit down, under a conviction of duty, to record the history of a chequered life; a life, though humble, yet filled with evidences of that merciful loving kindness in Him who sufferers not a sparrow to fall to the ground without His knowledge. 
If some of the incidents and sketches recorded seem to be trivial or out of place I would simply say by way of explanation that my design is to show the current of the mind in the two different phases of my life; the period when in nature's darkness I followed the courses of the world; and the period when by God's grace

3
ordered, about this time, to Council Bluffs, a fort on the Missouri river, in the then Territory of Missouri, and I was but a few days old when he removed to Governor's Island, in New York harbor. Here we remained but a few days, when we went to Philadelphia, and from thence we took up our journey upon horseback for Pittsburgh. I was but six weeks old when we left Philadelphia, and was carried in a basket before the saddle by one of the soldiers. The journey was a long and tedious one, over hills and through vallies and rivers, but Got preserved all our lives and kept us in health to the end. 
A few days were spent in Pittsburgh to remit? and fit up the boats for the descent of the Ohio river, and the ascent of the Mississipi and Missouri, which were then navigated by keelboats only. At this time too the river banks were lined with many hostile tribes of Indians, but God was still with us, and we passed them all with little or no molestation. The details of this journey have passed from my memory, and therefore I must pass to the time to which memory carries me back. 
When about six years old my father was ordered to the command of Fort St. Peters, on the Minesota river, in the then North West Territory; and from this time I can trace my history from memory; but having no date to guide me, I shall give each event as near their singular order as possible, without stating time accurately,

2
I put on the new man and enjoyed the blessed hope of eternal life through faith in the Lord Jesus Christ. 
With most persons who write their histories it is usual (whether it be for their own gratification, or for the public eye) either to pass lightly over the days of their childhood and commence at the time when ambition, or some other potent charm caused them to throw off the restraint imposed by parental rule and they enter the world of pleasure, toil and anxiety the undisputed  masters of their own wills and actions. In this I will not follow their example, for memory carries me back to a very early period and the incidents previous to that time have been so often related to me by old soldiers and domestics that few have slipped my recollection, although most of those incidents have nothing to do with me personally. I deem it unnecessary to enter into a detailed account of my parents. My father's galantry and bravery during the war of 1812-'15 is too well known to require eulogy from his son. Tippecanoe, Erie, unclear, Brownstown, Detroit, Plattsburgh and many other spots known to fame as sacred to the cause of liberty, were never a disgrace to him. My mother is a lineal descendent of Judge Shipwell the Regicide of Cromwell's time. 
Jany. 1 of 1829. I was born in the beautiful village of Plattsburgh, on lake Champlain, New York, on the 8th day of November 1816. My father, being a Colonel in the United States army, was

other portions of my body swolen enormously. The anticipated pleasures of the day were spoiled, and I lay several days in great pain and in danger of death; but after a severe struggle God rendered the means used effectual to my recovery. 
I have often thought of this incident and wondered why it had not made me wiser through life, and taught me not to suffer my curiosity to get the better of my judgment, especially when I have seen so man who have made themselves miserable for life by indulging in a disposition to learn what they should not have known. As I destroyed the habitation of the innocent bees, so has the happiness of many families been destroyed by the prying curiosity of others, who have also brought on themselves retributive justice. 
The following winter a party of men, who were driving a herd of cattle to the Fort, were waylaid by the Indians. The men were all killed and the cattle driven off. As soon as my father heard of the outrage he sent a body of soldiers to punish the Indians and recover the cattle. In doing this they handed the savages roughly, killing quite a number. This, of course, renewed their hostility and they resolved upon revenge. 
Wanata was head chief of the Dacotah nation. This renowned Indian is, or was, as familiar to the ears of the people of the northwest as that of King Philip in the east,

4
trusting that my narative, however simple it may appear, may be received as an "unvarnished tale" designed, not from any motive of notoriety, but that God may be glorified for "His wonderful works to the children of men." To my mind, the way He has led me through all these years teaches me that, although but a worm of the dust, His guiding and sustaining hand has always been over and around me in a remarkable manner, and that He has so preserved me for some purpose of His own; and may He receive all the honor and glory. 
During the first summer of my residence at Fort St. Peters there was a grand review of the troops, on the occasion, I think, of the visit of the Inspector General. To get a better view of the parade I climbed to the top of a high stump. I soon discovered that this stump was partially hollow and nearly filled with what appeared to be dry leaves. Child like I took a stick and began to stir these leaves. Instantly I was completely enveloped by a cloud of bumble bees that soon covered me with their stings, from the pain of which I became frantic, dancing for a few moments upon the top of the stump like a showman's monkey under the whip, and then falling to the ground pursued by the bees. My cries of agony soon brought a squad of soldiers to  my relief, who succeeded in driving off the bees after a hard fight. I was taken home entirely blind from the stings, and my head, hands, and

7
feathers, showing the number of warriors he had slain in battle, and dangling from each heal was a wolf's tail. 
Previous to the killing of the first party of drovers, related above, the vigilance of my father had revealed to him evident signs of jealousy and turbulence among the Indians, and Wanata had declared himself opposed to the establishment of a military station in the Territory, it being in his estimation an infringement of the rights of his people, and he remonstrated decidedly against it. Remonstrance being in vain he assembled his warriors and sent them out in small parties to destroy every white man who should cross their paths. 
Satisfied that a more courageous system of warfare must be inaugurated if he would succeed in expelling the enemy he resolved to strike a decisive blow against the Fort itself. After endeavoring for some time to draw the garrison into an ambuscade without success he withdrew his warriors and made overtures for peace, and then formed a plan for its capture and massacre within the walls of the fort. With this this design he sent messengers to Col. Snelling requesting permission to enter the fort with a few of his principal warriors, for the purpose of having a "talk" to settle the differences between them. The request was granted; but Col. Snelling

6
and he was equally great, and swayed the will of his people with equal intelligence and courage. He was celebrated not only for his warlike character, but for his natural abilities as a man and a gentleman. In person he was tall, athletic and perfectly formed, having a decided majestic and dignified carriage. His dress was truly aboriginal, but neat, and even elegant. It consisted of a shirt of check calico well made and ruffled, a coat, leggins and moccosins of hansomely tanned deer skin ornamented with colored porcupine quills worked in hierogliphics, and the seams and borders fringed with colored loops, feathers, and hawk's bells. The coat and leggins were secured around the waist and, below the knees with try-colored sashes; the front of the coat being left open to show the silver ornaments fastened to the shirt front, which were presented to him by the United States and British governments. Around his neck he wore a necklas of griselly bear's claws, a trophy which he prized above all others, as the evidence of the greatest achievement of Indian prowess, and commemorating the death of a grisley bear which he had killed with his own hands. To kill but one of these ferocious beasts of the Rocky Mountains is considered by the Indians the crowning art of heroism; but Wanata had killed his unclear, and hence his elevation to then first place in the Dacotah nation. On his head he wore a large tuft of eagle's

They were directed to the council chamber,

They were then led out to the parade ground,

had been too long among the aborigines to be deceived by this artifice of aparent friendship, and therefore he made every preparation for any emergency.

    The plot was well laid, and, had a lep experienced officer been in command, would undoubtedly have been successful. Wanantas intentions were, to post an overwhelming body of savages in the forest which sumunded? the fort and enter with only fifty men. During the sitting of the council, and in the midst of his speech, the presentation to Col. Snelling of a wampum belt was to be the signal for the commencement of the murderous work, for which purpose each warrior had his weapons concealed under his blanket. while the greater part were to rise and dispatch the officers within, the remainder were to rush out and taking the guard by surprise were to open the gates and admit the whole savage horde, who were to have approached during the conclave, when an indiscriminate slaughter was to take place.
   On the day appointed the wiley chief fully announced of the succefs of his plan, gathered his warriors and disposed them to the vert best advantage, and with the friendly wampum in one hand and the pipe of peace in the other, he presented himself before the gates; but contrary to his expectation, he found them all- except the northern one_ closed and secured. This did not, however, shake his resolution, for, as he

character and standing among the wildmen of the
forest that alone could restore peace and keep their
turbulent nature under control.  The visits of Wanatta
to first St. Peters and to Fort Snelling were frequent
subsequent to the event, and never after did
he attempt hostile demonstrations against either;
but, on the contrary, his best efforts were put forth to
preserve peace.  His dwelling place was, however, too
remote to enable him at all times to exert his influence
with the tribes in the immediate vicinity of the fort,
and consequently repeated outrages were committed,
and although they could not be prevented,
Wanata was prompt in rendering justice when they
came within his jurisdiction.  I think I can say with
truth, as well as with pride and satisfaction, that
to the bravery and consumate skill of my father,
and to him only, a repetition of the Michilmiachian 
slaughter was saved to the country.
The following year a new
fort was commenced on the point of a hill, on the
west side of the Mississippi river, and about a mile
from Fort St. Peters, overlooking both the Mississippi
and Minnesota rivers, and commanding a large tract
of country in the rear.  My memory fails to call
to remembrance any incident during the (unclear)
of this Fort, which was named by the Government
after the Commandant, Fort Snelling except
the discovers of the bones of a colossal Indian,
which were unearthed in excavating the cel

10
and they themselves ejected from the fort in disgrace.
This was the most severe punishment 
they could have received; death to them
would have been far more preferable; it would
have made them martyrs in the eyes of their fellow
warriors; their death would have been most ample
revenged, and their memory treasured up with
undying fidelity, and an opportunity for exhibiting
their indomitable courage might have awed
their enemies.  As it was, they could not return
to their tribes with this vile stain of disgrace upon them.
It was necessary to wash it out in blood.
Blood alone could cleanse them.  Their
courage or fortitude must not, for a moment be
doubted by friend or foe.
There was but one way left to
make atonement for their want of ways, and the indignities
put upon them.  Wanata set the example
by making skewers of wood and thrusting them through
the fleshy parts of his arms and legs.  Some followed
in the same expectory act, while others cut and hacked
themselves with their knives.
This check to Wanata's ambition
so raised his respect for Col. Snelling that
he was ever after one of his firmest and unwavering
friends, and in after years he often spoke
of it with a nobility of feeling worth of a more
enlightened mind.  It also gave Col. Snelling a

ate antics of Lipcap, plunged into the river swam
ashore, and running up the bank reached the spot
to which I had floated just as I sank for the third
time.  He seized a pole, and by God's providence,
thrust it into the water right before me, calling out
to me to take hold of it.  I had sufficient consciousness
to understand the act and obey the instruction
and was pulled out, fainting immediately, on
the greensward, from exhaustion.
By this time a file of soldiers had reached the spot; and between two of them I was
conveyed to the arms of my dear mother; who having
been overcome with fright at the news of my
accident was lying upon her bed almost insensible.
Didn't this poor, dripping, half drowned
boy get one of the most loving hugs, and a shower
of the sweetest kisses and tears a boy ever got
from one of the very best of mothers.  I will tell
you just what I thought while enclosed in those
loving arms.  I thought I would like to fall in
to the water very often if it would always give
me as much happiness as I then felt.  I have
often thought since how wonderfully God preserved
me in that hour of danger, and how
wicked and ungrateful I have been in not
living to his honor and glory.  But this was
not the only time he interposed his gracious
arm, during my childhood days, to snatch me
from the jaws of death; praise be to his holy name.

12
Cellar of the commandants quarters, which if I remember
aught indicated a man over nine feet high.
The summer following its occupation 
I came near losing my life in a watery
grave.  It had rained hard during the morning,
and this making the afternoon favorable for fishing
I took my pole and line and repaired to the river bank,
near the foot of the hill.  Fish were abundant
and ravenous after the bait.  Bass, perch, sun-fish
pickerel, pike, cat and other fish abounded in the
river and made the sport of angling very lively.
The bank was wet and slippery from the rain, and
in my eagerness to pull out a fish that was too large
for my strength I lost my foothold and plunged,
feet foremost, into the stream, which was far beyond
my depth and being unable to swim I sank beneath
the water.  Two other boys, who were with me,
gave the alarm.  An old man, named Lipcape, who
was working in a garden nearby ran to the brink,
but instead of trying to rescue me began to dance
about like a madman, crying out at the top of his 
voice, "Henry is drownding" "Henry is drownding".
The sentinel on the hill overlooking the spot took
up the alarm, and seeing my hat floating down
the stream, called lustily for the "corporal of the
guard."  A young soldier, whom my father had saved
three or four years before from a similar fate,
and who was fishing from a canoe about half
a mile off also caught the alarm from the deeper

tecting the fort against attack from those questers.
The views from these towers were both varied
and beautiful.  Upon the north the headland
stretches out into a vast unbroken plain, relieved
by delightful groves of trees, which are
interspersed at intervals over the prarie like islands
in a lake.  On the east the majestic Mississippi
washes the base of the hill directly beneath
the wall, the opposite shore of which rises
almost abruptly into lofty mountains, surmounted,
like the western hills by a vast level "plateau"
extending as far as the eye can reach and
presenting one of the most lovely scenes in nature.
The south tower takes in a portion of the east
and west views, and also a southern view over
a large island for several miles, while far to
the west beyond the Minnesota river a mountain
chain is seen.  The hill upon which the
fort stands gradually descends on the western
side into a low rich plain of some hundreds
of acres, forming the east bank of the Minnesota
river.  Two miles north of the fort is 
the celebrated cascade Minnehaha (Laughing water);
And a most lovely and beautiful 
gift of God it was at that time, a very paradise
of nature.  How the hand of man has improved(?)
it I know not, for I have never visited it since
my boyhood's days.  Here I have wandered down
and along the grassy and forest covered slopes

14
About this time another party of drovers were attacked by the Indians
and the cattle stolen.  This outrage was promptly 
atoned for by the chief of the tribe.  Subsequently
another murder was committed farther
down the Mississippi.  The perpetrators were delivered
up and sent to St. Louis for trial.
I will pause here to describe
as well as I can from memory, - the new fort/Snelling).
It was one of the best (if not the best) constructed
fortifications on the western frontier.  It
was built entirely of stone and surrounded by a 
high and massive wall, this wall on the east,
south, and west sides starting from the sides
of the hill upon which it was built, appeared,
from a distance, to be a portion of the steep
declivity.  The south front was defended by a 
semi-circular tower one story high, sufficiently
large for twelve guns, and overlooked the Mississippi
river, southwards, and what was called
"the floo" a stream connecting the Mississippi with
the Minnesota, or St. Peters river, the main portion
of the Minnesota falling into the Mississippi
several miles below.  A circular tower four or
five stories high, and pierced for about forty
guns, commanded a large tract of country to
the north and north west.  At angles on the
east and west sides were placed two hexagonal
(I think) towers of six and twelve guns, pro-

17
described already to need any desertion from me.
About a mile from the fort on the banks of the Mississippi
is a charming spot called Coldwater, where
I spent many a delightful summers' day gathering
berries and in sporting around the cooling spring
which gives name to the place.  Far out upon the
prarie west of the falls of St. Anthony is a chain
of beautiful lakes, pure as crystal and transient
as the clearest glass, and abounding in fish.  All
these places may come up before us again in the course
of this narrative.
I will here relate an incident, which
should have been recorded before, and which had some
influence in the formation of my character.  When
about eight years of age my father presented me with
a pen knife (the first I ever had), of which I took much 
care; but in an unlucky moment while endeavoring
to whittle a stick - the blade snapped in two at the
handle.  Although my father was ever kind to me, yet 
I was fearful that this accident would excite his anger
and cause me either a severe whipping, or prevent
my ever receiving another gift.  I stood for sometime
revolving in my mind what would be the best course
to pursue - disliking to tell a falsehood, still dreading
to explore the truth.  Terror at last conquered,
and I ran to my mother exclaiming - "Mother! Mother!
I didn't break my knife!  Falsehood revealed
itself, and truly did - I fall into my own trap.  The
truth instantly flashed across her mind, and as my father

16
of the cool and placid stream gathering the
beautiful flowers that adorned the velvet robe
of lovliest green that covered our mother earth;
or sat beneath the musical sounds of the
Laughing water as it fell into the crystal like
basin at my feet enjoying in wrapped reverie
the heavenly influence which such creation
of the Almighty God must always impart to the
mind of man whether saint or sinner.  Oh!  how
often I have gone to the beautiful creation
of God to take the beautiful fish of the stream,
that sporting in the sunlight near the surface
flashed their golden and silver rays into my eyes
as they chased each other in gleeful pastime, urgently
approached the shore into the cooling shadow
of the trees, and I could not do it.  No sooner seated
within the magic circle of those laughing waters now
I was lulled into forgetfulness of all else save present
happiness; so serene and blissful that to bring
death into the scene seemed sacrilege.  Birds
were all around me carroling their sweetest notes,
the waters danced before me, the wind murmured
among the leaves above me with (unclear) sweetness,
and the flowers around me sent a delicious fragrance
to my nostrils.  How could death enter this
vale of exquisite delight; surely here, if no where else,
God is manifest in his works.
Eight miles north of the Fort 
are the Falls of St Anthony which have been too often div

19
birds that rose up before them continually, by causing
the fox or wolfe, or in chasing the deer.  The fourth
day, however presented them with nobler game and
gave the Count an opportunity to exhibit the intrepidity
his love of danger inspired on every suitable occasion.
It is a well known fact (among the Indians
at least) that the buffalo (bison) when not attacked is
perfectly harmless and will take no notice of the passing
traveler; but when wounded his ferocity is unbound,
and although pierced by many arrows he will turn
and assault the hunter with great fury, who, if not
well experienced in his business, not unfrequently
falls a victim of his temerity.  It was a herd of these
animals that filled the eyes of the Count with delight,
and he declared he would achieve what man never
before attempted.  His associate remonstrated
with him to no purpose.  He set before him the imminent
peril he ran, and pictured to his mind the
horrors attending the attempt to capture these beasts
even when a large number of huntsmen were engaged.
But all this only inflamed the Counts desires the
more, and furnished additional inducements for rucking
the contemplated attempt.  Finding his arguments
and entreaties in vain, Mr L - placed himself in a 
position the best calculated to protect the Count
from the consequences he knew would be the result
of his rashness, and with a regretful heart, yet steady
hand he awaited the issue.  The herd was about half
a mile distant, grazing with apparent unconscious

came in at that moment she made him acquainted
with what had happened.  He led me into an adjoining
room and demanded to see my knife; to which
I (unclear) for a long time, but in the end was forced
to yield.  He then told me that it was not his intention
to punish me for braking my knife, as it
was of but little consequence, and could have been
easily replaced had I told the truth; but as I had endeavored
to conceal the fact and thereby had been
guilty of a lie, it was his painful duty to chastise 
me - whenever I received a severe whipping; such
as I shall remember to the end of my life, and such
as every child who tells a lie should receive.
About this time Count Beltrami,
an Italian nobleman who was travelling on a tour
of discovery to the head waters of the Mississippi,
and gathering curiosities with which to enrich the
museums of his native country, became the guest of
my father and remained several weeks exploring
the country around the fort.  During one of these
excursions while crossing one of those vast praries,
which give such a charm to western adventure,
in company with Mr. I -, the latter, who was fond
of adventure proposed to extend their ramble 
for several days.  Nothing could have pleased the
Count more, particularly  as he was possesed of 
so good a guide, of a temperament so akin to his own.
For the first two or three days
they arrived themselves by shooting the various wild

this moment the sharp crack of L-s rifle was heard
and the missel of death, hurled from its jaws sank
deep into the forehead of the buffalo.  This brought
him to his knees, and the Count springing from his
saddle attacked him with his knife.  His impetuosity
nearly proved fatal to the Count, for the best,
although mortally wounded was not yet vanquished,
and summoning all his remaining strength, he
made a violent plunge at the Count and sent him
reeling to some distance.  At this juncture Mr L
came up and again discharging his piece, the ball
passed through the noble creature's heart and put
and end to his struggles.
Shortly after the Counts return
from this adventure, the celebrated chief
Wanata visited the fort, and the Count took a 
great fancy to his necklace of bears claws.  His desire
to possess it induced him to make repeated
applications for it, and offers of large sums of money,
trinkets and other articles prized by Indians; all
of which the chief positively refused to accept.
The Count as a "dernier resort" applied to my Mother -
who possessed much influence over Wanata and
the Indians generally, - and on several occasions had
procured for him what had before been pertinaciously
denied him - to intercede in his behalf.  In
compliance with this request she approached
Wanata with the best possible grace, and with a
smile that before had won many a favor before expressed,

20
ness of the near approach of man.  The Count rod
slowly towards them until within a few hundred
yards, when, waving his handkerchief in the air, he
put spurs to his horse and dashed into their midst.
The frightened animals fled in all directions making
the prarie ring with the clatter of their hoofs and
the roar of their bellowing.  Count Beltrami selected
the largest and finest looking bull, gave chase and 
soon overtook him.  By a dexterous maneuver he
brought his horse to the side of the bll, and giving
him a violent kick in the side, at the same time plunging
his knife into his back, he wheeled around and
galloped towards his companion.  Now commenced
the most exciting part of the adventure.  The buffalo
infuriated by the attack and pain, with the
blood straining from the wound, in his turn gave
chase, and the horse becoming frightened at the
bellowing of his pursuer, reared, plunged and made
violent efforts to throw his rider; but a vigorous
application of whip and spur again brought him
under subjection and he darted off which increased
speed.  The buffalo was, nevertheless, fast gaining
upon them, and their destruction seemed inevitable,
unless he could succeed in reaching the spot
where Mr I  lay concealed before he was overtaken.
The infuriated animal was now fearfully
near - a few more bounds would plant his horns
into the horses' flesh - with a bellow as of triumph
he now lowered his horns  for the attack - but at

23
who were friendly.  Though a savage by birth he possessed
traits of character that caused all who knew
him, both Christian and heathen, to respect and esteem
him; he was, in fact, one of nature's noblemen.
During one of his hunting excursions
the Rising Son took a violent cold, and was
supposed to be in a dying condition by his family
and friends.  My mother, during one of her rides,
met him, and remarking his sickly appearance,
took him home with her, sent for the army physician,
had suitable medicines administered to
him, which together with her own kind attentions,
and the blessings of God, restored him completely
to health in a few weeks.  For this act of kindness
he was ever after most grateful.  The best of 
everything in the shape of game was always laid
aside for his benefactress.  He would travel a hundred
miles, or more, to lay at her feet some fresh
token of his grateful heart.  Her children, also,
received a share of these overflowing attentions.
The most beautiful handiwork of his young squaws -
such as moccasins, belts &c were lavished upon
them.  In one instance, a beautiful bow and 
quiver of twenty four arrows were presented to 
me.  They were made out of the horns of an elk, the
bow being of that form always put into the hands 
of Cupid when painted by our artists, and was of
the most flexible quality and exquisite workmanship.
This present was made at the time

22
solicited him for the necklace.  The Chief, with equal
(unclear) of manners returned her compliments 
and replied.  "Madam, I will make you a present
of this necklace on one condition only; that you will reciprocate
the favor and grant me whatever I ask in return."
"I will give you," said he, after a pause, "this badge
of my prowess if you will cut off your hair and braid
it for me to wear in its place."  Now, be it known, that
my good mother had a very beautiful head of hair;
if being jet black, very silky, find and long, reaching
nearly to the ground as she stood, and of which she
was justly proud.  To part with this was impossible,
therefore the Count was obliged reluctantly to give
up all hopes of possession, the coveted prize, and
the Chief felt assured that his stratagem had
relieved him from all further importunity.
I will here related an instance
of Indian gratitude, which, in point of time should

The Rising Sun was a young
Chief of the Dacotah nation.  He was one of these
whose every lineament bespoke the man.  Formed in
the mould of perfect symmetry, with a step majestic
with self respect, he was bold in the chase and
valorous on the war path, yet mild and kind to all

his forefathers" were open before him; he had been
taught to comprehend the blessed atoning sacrifice
of the Divine Redeemer, and was ready and willing
to depart.  When the hour arrived when he was
called from life to immortality, he took the hand 
of my mother, and in pressing it to his lips with
an ecstasy of delight, and a grateful heart, his spirt fled -
"That Indian had a heart."

Two years after, when far distant

Chapter II.
A furlough - A trip eastward - The Portage - Tap river - Garden Bay - Mackinaw - Detroit and return.


In the spring of 1825 my father
obtained a furlough and left fort Snelling for Detroit,
by way of Green Bay.  We descended the Mississippi
river to Prarie Du Chien in a keel boat, where we
procured a Mackinaw boat, the only vessel by which
we could navigate the Wisconsin and its rivers.  Until
we arrived at the Portage between these two streams
our journey was barren of incident so far as my memory
serves me.  At the Portage our boat was conveyed
a distance of two miles on wheels, from the Wisconsin
to the Fox rivers.  Here we found the mosquitoes,
grubs and flies altogether too plentiful for comfort,
and were obliged to spread our nets, not to catch

Mackinaw at that time was
much the same as it is now and always was a pleasant
place of summer resort.  The town is small, and
the inhabitants not the most refined in the world, but
what is better very cordial, polite and hospitable.  They
cannot furnish all the delicacies of the east, but they
can provide you with the best fish and potatoes the
world produces, for white fish and Mackinaw potatoes
are renowned throughout the country.  Besides, of
you want for amusement, you can pay a visit to the
"Sugarloaf"- a singular conical rock rising to a considerable
height - the "Cave of Sculls," or to the "Natural Bridge,"
almost as famous as the one in Virginia,
guides being always in readiness to conduct you thither.

  Our journey up the Fox river and down the Wisconsin was marked by no incident uncommon to such travelling, but after we had entered the Mississippi we were overtaken by winter, which set in unusually early this year, and on lake Pipin? we were caught in a storm which made entire shipwreck of our keelboat. The storm came upon us while sailing near the eastern shore where the bluffs rise precipitously, in a bold rocky face, directly from the waters edge, without an intervening sand beach as in many other places. Against these rocks our boat beat with such violence as to cause her to spring a leak, and we had but just sufficient time to pass the cliffs and to secure her to the shore, and flee to the land when she sank to the bottom carrying down every thing with her. Here we had to devote several days to raising her and drying the clothing, bedding, and such other articles as the water had not entirely destroyed. After repairing damages we proceeded but had not gone more than two thirds of the way across the lake before the ice obstructed our furcut word

  At length, in the year 1824, the Yacs were aroused to a determination to retaliate, adn a chosen band of forty five set out in search of a small party of Yonix who were said to be prowling about their hunting-grounds.   The animosity existing between the whole Dacotah nation and the Chippewas has long been a matter of comment among residents of, and visitors to, the Northwest territory. For ages it has existed, and, in all probability, will only cease when one of the other of those extensive tribes is totally exterminated from the face of the earth.
  The summer following (1827) the last mentioned occurrence a still greater act of treachery and outrage was committed by the Sioux upon the Chippewas.
  Flatmouth, a venerable chief of the Chippewa tribe, accompanied by his son and heir, the renowned Walking Thunder, and  about fifty men women and children of his tribe had arrived at the fort and pitched their wigwams on the bottom land at the fort of the hill upon which the fort stands. The object of their visit was to receive the presents annually distributed among them by the United States government, and make arrangements with the traders in that vicinity for the sale of the proceeds of their next winter's hunt.

  One of the amusements of the officers of the fort was to spend several days at a time in camp at lake Calhenn? fishing. This sheet of water is one of a chain of small inland lakes commencing about six miles from the fort and extending many miles northerly and north westerly. They are all exquisitely beautiful sheets of water, with a country around and about them of the most Eden like loveliness. although it gives a true picture of two of the most prominent traits in the Indian character, their esteem for the brave and detestation of cowardice. No sooner were the unhappy victims prostrate than, both Sioux and Chippewas rushed in a body to the warrior who had exhibited such heroic courage, plunged their knives into his still palpitating heart and while seeking with his blood drew them between their lips and drank the ensanguine stream with a satisfaction and delight unsurpassed even by their love for their favorite fire-water-or whiskey; assigning as a reason for so disgusting and act that the blood of one so brave would strengthen their hearts and give them additional courage. This ceremony over, they then proceeded to the body of the coward and treated it with every indignity they could invent; kicking it about like a foot ball; stamping out its teeth, spitting in the face, and pulling it about by the hair. It was then dragged to the brow of the hill and thrown over as fit only for the carrion crown and the wolf. The brave warrior, on the contrary, was buried with pomp, honor, rites and ceremonies due to the brave and customary among them.

  The summary proceedings in this affair restores peace and quietness to the country, although the fears of Flatmouth obliged my father to furnish him with an escort home.

                                                                 Chapter IV
                                                        The story of John Tully   
  If my reader will take the map of North America, and spread it before him, and search for a place called Pembina?, he will find it situated on the Red river of the North, a stream sunning due north and emptying itself into lake Winnepeg. The town, or rather the plan of the town, is a latitude 49° 10' and longitude 97. 
  It is a cold and dreary waste, unfit for the dwelling of civilized man, unless he can be content to subsist upon the spoils of the chase and fish of the river. Yet at this place a powerful Scotch nobleman once endeavored to plant a colony; as the government of Great Britain had granted him a patent for a large track of land in the vicinity; by which he endeavored to increase his wealth by unclear upon the honest but simple Swiss peasantry.

Though his misrepresentations, or those of his agents, a large number of these deluded peo- cut word

67
cut word fa-tigues of the journey enabled them to do so, they commenced plowing and planting their farms, notwithstanding that they were greatly disappointed in the appearance of the promised and expected paradise. They found too late that the cupidity and avarice of a lord had led them to hope for what he knew could never be realised and they wished they had, like their fellows countrymen, been content to remain at Quebec. But they concluded to "make the best of a bad bargain', and went to work cheerfully, the more so as all who left their native land together had thus far survived the accidents of land and sea. Houses and barns were built and farms measured off an fenced in. The season was favorable to an abundant crop and they rendered all praise and thanksgiving for their present blessings to Him to when it was due, from when all blessings flow; to Him they looked with perfect confidence for future preservation and happiness. Oh! it is a beautiful religion, that teaches us to put our whole trust in an all-wise, all-powerful God, who, in His bountiful goodness is ever ready and willing to help those who love Him and call upon Him in every time of need, and whose existence all nature proclaims with truthfulness and grandeur.

  The Indian potatoe is a delicious bulbous root about the size and shape of a hen's egg, and of a greyish color. It is found in all the marches of the Northwest territory. It is always roasted in the ashes, or between hot stones buried in the ground, as boiling destroys its exquisite flavor.  In order to obtain this vegetable the Indians are obliged to walk into the water up to their waists and then dig them up with their hands or cooked sticks; and it cooks very funny to see nothing but the dark round backs of fifty, and sometimes an unclear, Indians moving just above water, while the heads, arms and legs are under it. The scene is often enlivened by numbers of little pappooses? swimming and diving about in all directions.
